intro: Vitis vulpina var. parvifolia, commonly known as the small-leaf muscadine grape, is a deciduous vine native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its small, elliptical leaves that are typically 2–5 cm in length. The plant produces small, dark purple berries that are edible and have a musky aroma. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained, loamy soils. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value and as a source of fruit for both humans and wildlife.
